channel.description: http://emotiv.com/ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotiv_Systems#Emotiv_EPOC I have this, I got it in the mail from the Philippines a few days ago, and I have to admit it's really fucking awesome. Although it's kind of hard to control my thoughts with it (it'd probably be easier for other people who are better at focusing though), it works great as a head tracker even if you don't use the sensors. I haven't tried it with many games as I have access to shit computers only at the moment, but from what I've tried with AssaultCube it's amazingly useful.

item.title: Emotiv EPOC
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

It is, although the wireless aspect is pretty limiting. The position of the headset has to be in a certain area or else the reception from the usb isn’t good enough for the program to pick up the signals well. I can’t use it with my desktop until i move things around/get a usb hub Then again this is the very first version, probably would have been a better idea to wait until it had been revised… oh well, still fun :p. It’s annoying, though, because the sensors have to be removed from the headset after you stop using it and you have to reapply saline to them about every hour and a half to keep the readings accurate while using it, but I don’t really think there’s any way around that.

Emotiv Systems

Emotiv Systems is an Australian electronics innovation company developing technologies to evolve human computer interaction incorporating non-conscious cues into the human-computer dialog to emulate human to human interaction. Developing brain–computer interfaces based on electroencephalography (EEG) technology, Emotiv Systems produced the EPOC near headset, a peripheral targeting the gaming market for Windows, OS X and Linux platforms.
